Award.AwardTitle: TC: Small: Secure the Electrical Power Grid: Smart Grid versus Smart Attacks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Growing energy demands and environmental concerns have significantly increased the interest of academia, industry, and governments in the development of a smart electric power grid. Security is one of the key aspects of power systems. The objective of this research is to advance methods of vulnerability analysis and to develop innovative responses to maintain the integrity of power grids under complex attacks (both cyber attacks and physical failures). This research will contribute to developing robust, secure, and reliable future smart grid systems.

Unlike many of the existing efforts that focuses on abstract topological structure or load-based analysis, this project considers both network topology and intrinsic power flow characteristics to understand system behavior in complex power grid attacks. This includes single-node and multiple-node vulnerability analysis, development of new risk-aware metrics, spatial-temporal attacks with consideration of timing and location, and multifaceted attacks augmented by link failures. Knowledge of power grid system behavior under attack scenarios will allow us to develop new defense strategies.

As power and energy systems have become one of the key technology and economic development focuses across the world, this project will have far-reaching impacts at different levels. This includes enhancing national power system security, providing technical support to government agencies and policy-makers for the U.S. energy sustainability community, and student education and workforce preparation in this field. The integrative educational and outreach approaches will also provide a unique platform to encourage women and minority students to the critical Electrical/Computer Engineering disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The power grid is one of the most complex systems and has become the target of cyber and physical attacks. This project tackled an essential aspect of the power grid security: cascading failures. Unlike many of the existing efforts that either purely focuses on the topology and load of the grid, this project considered power grid structure, power flow analysis, and complicated attack actions that involve coordination in both spatial and time domain.  The team has discovered advanced attack strategies ranging from single-node attacks, multiple-node attacks, joint node-link attacks, to spatial-temporal attacks.  In-depth investigation of these attacks provided critical insights and guidelines for designing defense solutions that improve the grid robustness, security, and reliability.

The team has developed a power grid security test bed with the integration of PowerMap database (including all North America electrical infrastructure), modeling and simulation toolsets, and geographic information system (GIS) based data visualization capability. This test bed is a powerful evaluation and demonstration platform for power grid security research community, as well as the network security community.

The outcomes of this project are significant, ranging from new knowledge and methods to advance the power grid security research and development, to education and outreach programs across electrical, energy, security, and computer disciplines. Over the project period, the team published a series of high impact journal and conference papers (e.g., IEEE International Conference on Communications (ICC’14) Best Paper, IEEE International Joint Conference on Neural Networks (JCNN’16) Best Student Paper, IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security cover page highlighted paper, IEEE Communications Society Best Readings on Communications and Information Systems Security, the first-kind of comprehensive survey paper dedicated on smart grid cyber-physical security), graduated 4 Ph.D. students (two in academia and two in industry), received numerous IEEE awards (e.g., IEEE Computational Intelligence Society Outstanding Early Career award), among others.  

The results generated in this project directly bene?t the power engineering and network security communities, and can be generalized to other complex systems such as social network, transportation network, communication network, to name a few. Besides their bene?ts to academia and industry, the research results also provide technical supports to the government agencies and policy-makers for achieving the long-term U.S. energy sustainability objective. Finally, the educational and outreach activities, including an IEEE workshop, development of new course materials/modules, and outreach to the Community College of Rhode Island (CCRI, the largest community college in New England, with about 60% female students), has provided a unique platform to educate and train graduate and undergraduate students in research and encourage women to study Electrical/Computer Engineering disciplines.
